content.description:
Decent route that climbs a little better than it looks.  The route stays fairly sustained for most of its length, aside from an easy ramp at about 2/3 height.  Finish up a steep headwall with a left-trending crack.  The crux is probably between the last bolt and the anchors.

High first bolt - you can stick clip, come in from the right (easier but more circuitous), or come in from the left (harder but direct and dirty).
content.location: Middle of North Star Wall, just right of a mossy and dirty offwidth.

content.description: Far right dark slab on the wall (Past Childhood's Beginning). Old bolts and anchor.  Thin slab climbing.
content.location: Far right dark slab on the wall (Past Childhood's Beginning).

content.description: Interesting climbing on Tuolomne-style crystals. Pull an awkward bulge, then move into a sustained crux from bolts 3-5 on small edges and knobs. Pull another bulge that's harder than it looks, then finish up the slab.
content.location: Right side of North Star Wall, follows an arête to the left of an arching crack.

content.description: This extremely unique route is one of the most interesting routes in Donner. Start off the route with a brutal mantel on a large roof which is followed by thin face climbing. From here attack an overhanging pocketed face with brutally thin moves on slopers and pockets to the top.
content.protection: 7 bolts lead to a 2 bolted anchor. Rap off.
content.location: This route is located about 100ft to the left of Childhood's End 5.10d and is one of the first routes you will see when getting to the wall through the second approach described on North Stars Wall.

content.description: Good friction slab climbing with a few big holds thrown in.  If you don't bring any gear (.75 or 1" cam), expect a run-out to the anchors.
content.location: Far right side of the wall, look for the line of bolts with black hangers.

content.description:
This holds one of the most cleanest and spectacular dihedrals in Donner Summit. Beautiful hand jams solid feet make this 5.10 looking dihedral 5.6. The downside is that the dihedral section is only about 15ft high and the rest of the route only gets one star.

If only the dihedral section was a hundred foot route, this would probally be one of the best climbs.
content.protection: Thin pieces with some TCU's for the bottom. The dihedral takes small cams up to 2 inches. Same as the other routes, there is no bolted anchor.
content.location: This is located to the far right of Childhood's Beginning and has and ok start into a 4 star dihedral hand crack.

content.description: This is one of the best 5.10+ trad routes at Donner and is very similar to the routes on Devil's Tower in Wyoming except much shorter. The crux is continuous through the first dihedral on thin lyebacks and small finger locks. Scramble up 5th class to the base of the dihedral and belay on a flat ledge about 1/3 of the way up the cliff. This route looks impossible to protect from the base, but holds solid pro.
content.protection: Small pieces ranging from nuts, TCU's, and a few larger cams up to 1 inch. Rap anchors. 60m rope works with little to spare.
content.location: This is the first obvious dihedral on the wall and is the left dihedral of the two.

climbs.name: Childhood's Beginning
climbs.fa: Karl Hammer, John Hoffman, Paul Firestone

content.description: This beautiful dihedral is one of the few 5.8 splinter finger cracks at Donner Summit and follows a thin splinter finger crack on the arete and then traverses into the dihedral. Sustained and a bit tricky for the grade, but holds solid pro.
content.protection: Small pieces consisting of mostly TCU's and some cams up to 1 inch. Rap anchor. 60m rope works, just barely.
content.location: This is located to the right of Childhood's End 5.10d and starts the same as childhood's End. Scramble up 5th class to the flat ledge about 1/3 the way up the cliff. Instead of entering the dihedral follow 2 parrelel cracks on the right to the top of a huge ledge then follow the thin splinger finger crack on the arete to the top.

content.description:
Break it Out is a somewhat discontinuous, mostly dihedral crack system that keeps throwing liebacks, some thin crack and even a bit of the offwidth at you to keep you honest. Honestly, it is a pretty awkward lead and a bit of a head sketch at times because the knobby rock here seems a bit brittle and placements therefore can seem slightly suspect.

Nonetheless, it is fairly good climbing that'll get you nice and warmed up.
content.protection: doubles from fingers to 3". One 4" piece rec'd. Chain anchors.
content.location: On the far left side of North Star Walls, the crack system just right of the bolted slab arete, Diamond in the Rough.

content.description: Another Summit obscurity. Stemming dihedral to a slightly less-vertical section. The right-facing corner acts as a water funnel in early-season, and can get dirty. However, when it cleans up, it's quite good.
content.location: Obvious black dihedral between 2 bolted routes.

content.description:
Start up an unprotected but well-featured face, then layback left out the arching crack/seam.  Clip the last bolt on "Kids With Guns", over the small bulge, and finish at that route's anchors.

The gear is small and a bit fiddly - probably only recommended for the confident 5.10 leader.  Easy to toprope with a directional after climbing "Kids With Guns".
content.location: Obvious left-leaning arch on the far right side of North Star Wall.
